summary: the results showed that the optimal multiplex RT-LAMP reaction was obtained with primer sequences shown in Table 1 and the primer concentrations described in Materials and Methods. at 63 °C, the best amplification efficiency was observed for all the three HA subtypes (A/H5, A/H7 and 2009A/H1) and thus 63 °C was considered to be optimal temperature for the multiplex RT-LAMP reaction. GAATGGTA 38 H5-BIP GGTACGCTGCAGACAARGAATGAGTTGACCTTATTGGTGA 40 H5-LF GGTGRWACCCATACCAACCA 20 H5-LB CYACTCAAAAGGCAATAGATGGA 23 A/H7 H7-F3 TGTCTGTTTTTGACAG 21 H7-FIB GTATGTGAATCCCATTGCTCTGAGG. target-specific primary invasive reaction are used to drive a secondary invasive reaction. when the target is present, the cleaved HP cannot trigger the aggregation of AuNPs, leading to a red color of the reaction. when the target is absent, the Hp is intact, leading to the aggregation of AuNPs. multiplex RT-LAMP amplification reactions for A/H5 (d), A/H7 (e) and 2009A/H1 (f) were also monitored by real-time turbidity detection. detection limits for A/H7 and 2009A/H1 were both 101 copies of synthetic RNA. detection limit for A/H5 was 102 copies of synthetic RNA. new tab RNA extracted from influenza viruses A/H5N1, A/H7N9, 2009A/H1N1 or each control virus was used as RT-LAMP template, respctively. cascade invasive reaction and gold nanoparticle hybridization were further identified in three target-specific detection tubes. mRT-LAMP-IRNH detected 6/6A/H5, 18/18A/H7 and 27/28 2009A/H1. the sensitivity and specificity for detecting A/H5 were 100% (6/6) and 100% (82/82), respectively. for 2009A/H1, the sensitivity and specificity were 96.4% (27/28) and 100% (60/60), respectively. at 63 °C, the best amplification efficiency was observed for all the three HA subtypes (A/H5, A/H7 and 2009A/H1). according to the amplification curves obtained by real-time turbidimeter, 50 min was selected as the optimal incubation time. in mRT-LAMP-IRNH, the multiplex RT-LAMP amplicons were further identified by cascade invasive reaction and nanoparticle hybridization. a target DNA is firstly hybridized with an upstream probe (Up) and a downstream probe (Dp), forming a one-base overlapping structure at the 3′-end of the Up. the blue arrow indicates the site of cleavage. sensitivity of the mRT-LAMP-IRNH assay was determined by testing ten-fold serial dilutions of viral RNA transcripts on two separate days. after 50 min of amplification, diluted RT-LAMP products were added into the invasive reaction mixture to perform cascade invasive reactions for each target. the detection limits for all the three HA genes (A/H5, A/H7 and 2009A/H1) were 101 copies of synthetic RNA by presenting red detection limits for multiplex RT-LAMP amplifications were also monitored by a real-time turbidimeter. the detection limit for A/H7 and 2009A/H1 was 102 copies of synthetic RNA. sensitivity of cascade invasive reaction coupled with nanoparticle hybridization was higher than that obtained by mRT-LAMP-IRNH. the cascade invasive reactions were performed with 09H1-UP, 09H1-DP and HP. 88 clinical specimens were subject to mRT-LAMP-IRNH assay. sensitivity and specificity were 100% (6/6) and 100% (82/82) respectively. the mRT-LAMP-IRNH assay had an overall sensitivity and specificity of 98.1% (51/52) and 100% (36/36), respectively. the results of real-time RT-PCR were used as the reference standard. the main drawbacks of virus culture are that it can only detect live viruses. agarose gel electrophoresis, turbidity or fluorescence detection35,36, lateral flow dipstick23, or even visual inspection37,38. these methods are robust and reliable, but detect total amplification products in a reaction and are thus limited to detection of a single target. NH assay developed in this study is a cost-saving method. it is more suitable for multiple-target detection of limited amount and/or precious nucleic acids. unknown clinical specimens with co-infection can also be distinguished without using any equipment. mRT-LAMP-IRNH offers the same high specificity. assay were found to be 101 copies of synthetic RNA for all three targets. the detection limit for A/H5 obtained by mRT-LAMP-IRNH was ten times higher than that obtained by real-time turbidity detection. sensitivity of the mRT-LAMP-IRNH assay was compared to that obtained by real-time RT-PCR. a highly sensitive and specific mRT-LAMP-IRNH assay was developed for the first time in this study. this assay can detect three prominent subtypes of influenza viruses (A/H5, A/H7 and 2009A/H1). the advantages of cost-saving and no requirement of any complicated instrument make this assay more suitable for low-equipment setting laboratory use and for on-site testing. four known positive poultry cage surface swabs were collected from live poultry markets. all these isolates and specimens were stored at 80 °C until use. RNA was extracted from 200 l of samples with a MagNA PureTM system. the sequence information of the final selected multiplex RT-LAMP primers is shown in Table 1. the cascade invasive reaction upstream probes and downstream probes were designed using the Universal Invader Design Software version 1.2.4 (Third Wave Technologies, Inc., Madison, USA) modification of AuNPs were synthesized by reducing tetrachloroauric acid with trisodium citrate according to the protocol described previously46. transmission electron micrographs were taken to measure the size of synthetic particles (an average diameter of 13 nm) the 20 l invasive reaction was carried out with 0.2 M upstream probe, 0.2 M downstream probe, 0.2 M hairpin probe, 100 ng AfuFEN enzyme. reactions were run at 85 °C for 1 min followed by 63 °C for 20 min. clinical specimen analysis To investigate the feasibility of our methodology for clinical sample analysis, 88 clinical specimens were collected and analyzed by mRT-LAMP-IRNH assay. the parallel analysis by our in-house real-time RT-PCR assays for influenza A/H5, A/H7 and 2009A/H1 was recommended by WHO48,49,50. all the three assays had been validated against viral culture and commercial real-time RT-PCR kits. 84 nasopharyngeal swabs were collected from influenza-like cases. 48 were identified positive for influenza A viruses including 18A/H7N9, 2A/H5N1, and 28 2009A/H1N1. 4 known positive poultry cage surface swabs were collected from live poultry markets. primers and probes were designed using conserved regions of the HA gene for each influenza A subtype. primers were designed using the PrimerExplorer version 4 program (Eiken Chemical Co., Tokyo, Japan) the feasibility and specificity of the primers were subsequently checked by BLAST search with sequences in GenBank. multiplex RT-LAMP reaction was carried out with a RNA Amplification Kit. reaction mixture containing 1 l of distilled water was used as no-template controls. reaction mixture containing 1 l of distilled water was used as no-template controls. a heat-block (ThermoStat Plus, Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany) was used for RT-LAMP amplification reaction. three target-specific cascade invasive reactions were performed. a total of 88 clinical specimens were collected and analyzed by mRT-LAMP-IRNH assays. the amplicons from each RT-LAMP reaction were further identified by cascade invasive reaction and gold nanoparticle hybridization as described before in three separate target-specific detection tubes.
